unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: Two-Proportion $Z$-Test Risks
question_text:
In a survey done in a small town last year, $8$ out of $12$ randomly selected people said they approve of the job the mayor is doing.
The following year, $10$ different people are randomly surveyed, and of these, only $6\text{ people}$ approve.
Why would it be inappropriate to perform a two-proportion $Z$-test to determine whether the mayor’s approval rating has changed?

choices.text: It is illogical to perform an inferential procedure like a two-proportion $Z$-test when the population data is already known.
The data does not come from simple random samples.
The populations are most likely NOT at least 10 times each sample.

At least one of the following is not at least 5:
N1⋅(pooled p)
N2⋅(pooled p) 
N1⋅(1-pooled p) 
N2⋅(1-pooled p)

The combined sample sizes are only 22
, which is too small.

solution:
Two proportion Z tests require a roughly normal sampling distribution of the difference of sample means. As long as the values mentioned in Choice 'D' are at least 5 (or some textbooks require 10), this distribution will be roughly normal and the condition will be met.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect; this situation deals with two samples to determine how people feel about the mayor from one year to the next. Therefore, an inference is reasonable in this situation.

Choice 'B' is incorrect; the problem makes clear that the data comes from simple random samples.
